par.text: Iodine is a non-metallic element with a characteristic pungent odour and a lustre resembling metals. It is a greyish-black solid. It sublimes easily into a deep violet vapour, strongly irritating to the eyes, nose and throat. Iodine is only slightly soluble in water, but readily soluble in organic solvents, such as ethanol –
OH. Chemically very reactive, iodine reacts with metals to form iodides, for example magnesium iodide – Mg

; with hydrogen it forms hydrogen iodide, HI. Iodine was discovered by a French chemist, Bernard Courtois, in 1811; its properties were first studied and described by Gay-Lussac in 1813. The name Iodine is derived from the Greek
